Warning: Water already assessed in history.
Water Quality Assessor for Coffee Brewing
Bring your coffee to the ideal level
Your water was classified as "%1$s". Want to know exactly how to fix it? The Premium Optimizer calculates the recipe for you.

Not all water parameters are created equal. Based on current scientific consensus (including studies from the Specialty Coffee Association - SCA - and experts like Scott Rao), water quality for coffee is primarily determined by two factors:


1. Alkalinity (the most important factor)

Think of alkalinity as a "buffer" that neutralizes acids. It has the most direct impact on your coffee\'s flavor.

  • Very high alkalinity: Over-neutralizes the bright, tasty acids in coffee, resulting in a "flat," "dull," or "lifeless" brew.
  • Very low alkalinity: Offers no protection against corrosion in your machines and can result in an overly "acidic" or "sour" coffee.

2. Total Hardness (Calcium and Magnesium)

Hardness is crucial for extraction. Calcium and magnesium ions bind to flavor compounds in the coffee grounds and extract them into the water. Additionally, hardness is the main factor in scale buildup (incrustation) in your equipment.

  • Very high hardness: Causes rapid scale buildup, requiring constant maintenance.
  • Very low hardness: The water lacks "extraction power," resulting in a "weak" or "under-extracted" coffee.

pH, although monitored, is considered less impactful on the final flavor than alkalinity.

You\'ll notice that TDS (Total Dissolved Solids) and Sodium are part of our analysis. We are being transparent about how we handle them.


The "Ideal" TDS Myth

Older standards (like the 2011 SCAA chart) popularized the idea of an "ideal" TDS of 150 mg/L. However, more recent SCA studies (like the 2018 manual) and industry experts are clear: TDS, by itself, is not a good indicator of quality.


Why? A TDS of 150 can be composed of ideal minerals (calcium and bicarbonate) or undesirable minerals (like table salt). The total number doesn\'t tell the whole story.


Our (Honest) Approach

We include TDS and Sodium in our score because we know they are a popular concern and appear on many water reports. We use the 2011 SCAA reference ranges to evaluate them.

However, to ensure your score reflects what really matters for flavor, TDS and Sodium have a very low weight in our final calculation. They serve as "tie-breakers," but will never define whether your water is good or bad.

There is no "magic number" or single standard for perfect water. The ideal water for espresso might be slightly different from that for pour-over. Therefore, our system is based on optimal ranges and importance weights.


Our scoring system synthesizes data from multiple sources (including various SCA standards and expert research) to create an "app philosophy" that prioritizes flavor and equipment safety.


The Weighted Calculation

Your final score (from 0 to 100) is a weighted average. This means we prioritize what matters most:


  • Alkalinity: Receives the highest weight (50% of the score).
  • Total Hardness: Receives a medium weight (30% of the score).
  • TDS and Sodium: Receive a minimal weight (10% each).

This ensures that water with great alkalinity and hardness will always get a good score, even if the TDS is outside the popular "ideal." And conversely, water with a TDS of 150 will receive a low grade if the alkalinity (the most important factor) is poor.

The label scanning function uses the camera to speed up chemical data entry. However, capture success faces significant challenges: ‚Ä¢ Lack of Standard: Water brands do not follow a single format. Tables can be vertical or horizontal, and mineral names can be abbreviated (e.g., 'Ca' for Calcium). ‚Ä¢ Image Quality: Factors like bottle curvature, light reflections, condensation, and camera focus can degrade image quality and make text reading difficult. Therefore, the capture should be seen as an assistance tool. Always verify the captured values before proceeding with the assessment to ensure accurate results.
Discover the ideal mineral water for a perfect coffee, based on the science of extraction.
Coffee science is clear: Alkalinity (which controls acidity) and Hardness (which extracts flavor) are the most important factors.
Popular parameters like TDS (Total Dissolved Solids) are considered, but with less weight. Our system prioritizes what affects flavor.
Use our premium calculator to know exactly how many mineral drops to add and transform your water into the ideal SCA water.

Save your data to a JSON file
Learn how to use all features
You must first evaluate and save a water to be able to optimize it.
Restoring a backup will replace ALL currently saved histories and recipes. This action cannot be undone.

Local Storage

All your data is stored locally on your device, not in the cloud. This means:

  • Total Privacy: Your assessments and recipes never leave your phone
  • Works Offline: No internet needed to use the app
  • Your Data, Your Control: You decide when to backup or share

‚ö†Ô∏è Important

Since the data is local:

  • If you uninstall the app, you will lose all data
  • If you change phones, you will need to backup manually
  • We recommend backing up regularly in Settings

How to Backup

  1. Go to Settings (gear icon on the home screen)
  2. Tap Export Backup
  3. Choose where to save the file (Drive, WhatsApp, etc.)
  4. To restore, use Restore Backup
How to use the Optimization Calculator

üß™ Optimizing Your Water

The Optimization Calculator is a Premium feature that calculates exactly how many drops of each mineral to add to your water to make it ideal for coffee.

How It Works

  1. Assess your water: First, perform an assessment of your current water
  2. Save the result: Save the assessment to history
  3. Access the Optimizer: On the home screen, tap "Optimize Water"
  4. Choose the water: Select which water you want to optimize
  5. See the recommendations: The app shows how many drops to add

üìä Understanding the Results

The optimizer shows:

  • Drops needed: Exact amount of each mineral solution
  • Score before/after: How your water will improve
  • Achievable profile: The final values after adding the minerals
  • Warnings: Alerts if something is already ideal

‚öóÔ∏è Preparing the Solutions

You will need:

  • Calcium Chloride (CaCl‚ÇÇ)
  • Magnesium Sulfate (MgSO‚ÇÑ)
  • Potassium Bicarbonate (KHCO‚ÇÉ)

Important: The solutions must be prepared in specific concentrations. The app provides preparation instructions.

üí° Tips

  • Start with known mineral waters to test
  • Write down your favorite recipes
  • Experiment and compare different waters
  • Always add minerals gradually

üéØ Ranges instead of Fixed Numbers

The app\'s new philosophy works with ideal ranges instead of fixed values.

Why?

  • More Flexible: Accepts natural water variations
  • More Realistic: Better reflects the real world
  • Less Stress: You don\'t need to hit an exact number

üìä Scoring System

Each parameter has an ideal range:

  • Hardness: 17-85 ppm (ideal: ~51 ppm)
  • Alkalinity: 0-75 ppm (ideal: ~37 ppm)
  • Sodium: 0-30 ppm (ideal: ~15 ppm)

The closer to the center of the range, the better the score!

How to use the Blend Calculator üíß What is Blending?

The Blend Calculator is a feature that allows you to simulate mixing two different waters you have already saved (whether from your History or your Saved Recipes).

The app calculates the exact chemical profile and the resulting score of the mixture, based on the proportions you set.

ü§î Why Blend?

Blending is a powerful technique to:

  • Dilute: Take very "hard" water (e.g., 200 ppm Hardness) and mix it with "soft" water (like distilled or reverse osmosis, which you can save as a recipe with "0" for everything) to reach the ideal range.
  • Correct: Try to "fix" water with a bad parameter (e.g., very high alkalinity) by mixing it with another that has the opposite parameter (low alkalinity).
  • Experiment: Simply see what happens when you combine the profiles of two different mineral waters you have evaluated.

üìã How to Use

  1. Go to My Recipes (on the home screen).
  2. Select the "Blend" tab at the top of the screen.
  3. Tap "Select Water A" and choose a water from your History or Saved Recipes.
  4. Tap "Select Water B" and choose the second water.
  5. Enter the volumes (e.g., 700ml of A and 300ml of B).
  6. Tap Calculate Blend.

üìä Understanding the Results

The app will show the final chemical profile of the mix, the new score, and whether the mix resulted in ‚ú® Improvements (e.g., hardness entered the ideal range) or ‚ö†Ô∏è Warnings (e.g., sodium became too high).

If you like the result, you can Save the blend. It will appear in your "Recipes" list for future reference or even to be used in new blends!
Data backup and restore is an exclusive feature for Premium subscribers. Subscribe now to get access to this and other benefits!
